goodreads_match.title: Apology
goodreads_match.description:
(The) Apology (of Socrates) is Plato's version of the speech given by Socrates as he defends himself against the charges of being a man "who corrupted the young, did not believe in the gods, and created new deities". "Apology" here has its earlier meaning (now usually expressed by the word "apologia") of speaking in defense of a cause or of one's beliefs or actions.
This book was converted from its physical edition to the digital format by a community of volunteers. You may find it for free on the web. Purc...

raw.author: Horace

commentaries: The author directly quotes a line from Horace's 'Letters' to illustrate a point about personal concern or responsibility.

raw.author: Socrates
contexts: Even to make the well-known Socratic distinction between what one understands and what one does not understand, passion is required, and of course even more to make the characteristic Socratic movement, the movement, namely, of ignorance.

If faith is nothing but what philosophy makes it out to be, then Socrates already went further, much further, whereas the contrary is true, that he never reached it. In an intellectual respect he made the movement of infinity. His ignorance is infinite resignation.
I am thinking of Pythagoras and Socrates.
One may take Socrates as an example.
commentaries: The author references Socrates as the originator of a philosophical distinction and a characteristic intellectual movement, using them as an example to argue for the necessity of passion over mere reflection.
The author uses Socrates as a philosophical reference point, analyzing his intellectual stance as one of infinite resignation, which is contrasted with faith.
The author references Socrates as a thinker, linking him to the concept of self-knowledge and the discovery of evil within, without citing a specific written work.

The author uses Socrates as an intellectual tragic hero to illustrate the spiritual strength required at the moment of death, contrasting his ability to speak meaningfully with Abraham's paradoxical silence.

goodreads_match.title_without_series: The Encyclopaedia Logic: The Encyclopaedia of Philosophical Sciences 1 with the Zusatze

goodreads_match.description: A translation of Hegel's German text. It includes a bilingual annotated glossary, bibliographic and interpretive notes to Hegel's text, an Index of References for works cited in the notes, a select Bibliography of various works on Hegel's logic, and an Index."

raw.author: Plato
contexts: Opinions may be divided as to which rejoinder of Socrates is to be regarded as the decisive one, inasmuch as Socrates has been in so many ways volatilized by Plato.
commentaries: The author notes that Plato's philosophical interpretations have obscured the historical Socrates, making it difficult to determine which of Socrates' final statements is most authentic.

raw.author: Pythagoras
contexts: I am thinking of Pythagoras and Socrates.
If there can be any question of an analogy, the circumstance of the death of Pythagoras fumishes it, for the silence which he had always maintained he had to carry through in his last moment
commentaries: The author references Pythagoras as a thinker, linking him to the concept of self-knowledge and the discovery of evil within, without citing a specific written work.
The author cites Pythagoras as an example of maintaining silence until compelled to speak at death, drawing a parallel to the theme of necessary silence in Abraham's ordeal.

raw.author: Søren Kierkegaard
contexts: I will follow this with a sketch which involves the demoniacal. The legend of Agnes and the Merman will serve my purpose.
commentaries: The author references the legend of Agnes and the Merman as a source for a sketch involving the demoniacal, indicating its use as a narrative framework.

raw.author: Daub
contexts: what Daub38 means when he says that a soldier who stands alone at his post with a loaded gun in a stormy night beside a powder-magazine … will get strange thoughts into his head
commentaries: The author references Daub to illustrate the kind of profound and terrifying thoughts one might have in a moment of extreme isolation and danger, using this as an analogy for comprehending life's horror as a precursor to faith.

raw.author: Aristophanes
contexts: Let us imagine such an Aristophanes, such a Voltaire, a little altered, for he is at the same time a sympathetic nature, he loves existence, he loves men, and he knows that even though the reproof of laughter will perhaps educate a saved young race, yet in the contemporary generation a multitude of men will be ruined.
commentaries: The author references Aristophanes as a figure whose method of reproof through laughter could be ethically motivated, using him as an archetype to explore the dilemma of whether to speak out or keep silent.

raw.author: Cumberland
contexts: Thus Cumberland's Jew83is also a demon notwithstanding he does what is good.
commentaries: The author references Cumberland's character 'the Jew' as an example of a demoniacal nature despite performing good actions.
